lines.text: The last time that I trusted a dame was in Paris in 1940. She said she was going out to get a bottle of wine. Two hours later, the Germans marched into France.
Locked, from the inside. That can only mean one thing. And I don't know what it is.
I smell gas!
I can't help it, I'm old.
No, not that kind of gas. The kind that kills!
Well, sometimes my gas...
unnecessary.
I don't hear nothin'. What do you hear?
Double negative, and dog.
Did you see that?
No.
Neither did I.

Another diversion. He gives us meaningless clues to confuse us, dangles red herrings before our eyes, bedazzles us with bizarre banalities, while all the time precious seconds are ticking away towards a truly terrible murder still to come.
You're good, Charleston. You're not my kind of cop, but you're smart and you smell good. You're not a pansy, I know that, but what the hell are ya?
Classy, I suppose.
another test that could have cost us our lives, saved only by the fact that I am ENORMOUSLY well-bred.
...Lucky it wasn't me, or I'd be chopped liver by now.
Who do you think is the murderer?
Must sleep on it. Will know in morning when wake up.
But what if you don't wake up?
Then YOU did it.
I'm the greatest, I'm number one!
To me, you look like number two, know what I mean?
What DOES he mean, Miss Skeffington?
I'll tell you later. It's disgusting.
It is late, and my eyes are getting tired.
I thought they always looked like that.
Knock it off, Sam!
I apologize. This case is getting to me. I'm sorry, Slanty.
Um... thank you.

You've tricked and fooled your readers for years. You've tortured us all with surprise endings that made no sense. You've introduced characters in the last five pages that were never in the book before. You've withheld clues and information that made it impossible for us to guess who did it. But now, the tables are turned. Millions of angry mystery readers are now getting their revenge. When the world learns I've outsmarted you, they'll be selling your $1.95 books for twelve cents.
He's gone!
Who's gone?
The butler. Here's the key.
If butler gone, where you find key?
In his pocket.
What pocket?
The butler's pocket.
Butler gone but pocket still there?
Ten people for dinner and I'm serving them hot nothing. You can't get good help today.
Answer simple, but question very hard.
Twain picked up Sam in a gay bar.
I was working on a case! Working.
Every night for six months?
I will tell everyone that you wear a toupee.
They already know!
Then why do you wear it?
I didn't know that you knew.
I was in disguise in disguise in disguise. You work hard for fifty bucks a day in this racket.
WAS there a murder, or WASN'T there?
Killed good weekend. Drive, please.
Thank you. You are?
Bensonmum.
Thank you, Benson.
No, no, no, no, no... Bensonmum. My name is Bensonmum.
Bensonmum?
Yes, sir. Jamesir Bensonum.
Jamesir?
Yes, sir.
Jamesir Bensonmum?
Yes, sir.
How odd.
My father's name, sir.
What was your father's name?
Howard. Howard Bensonmum.
Your father was Howard Bensonmum?
Leave it be, Dickie. I've had enough.
Be careful on this road. It's treacherous.
Treacherous road like fresh mushroom. Must always...
[son drives car away from Charleston]
Idiot! Not finish fresh mushroom story! Idiot!
She murdered herself in her sleep, sir.
You mean suicide?
Oh no, it was murder, all right. Mrs. Twain HATED herself.
Up there, Dora, look - a blind butler.
Don't let him park the car, Dickie.
No pulse, no heartbeat. If condition does not change, this man is dead.
[a bomb is about to explode]
I've got an idea! I don't know if it will work but I've got to try. Turn around!
I've turned, Sam.
Whatever you do, don't turn around until I say so.

[turns around]
But Sam...
I SAID TURN AROUND!
Yes, Sam.
Good! Cause... I think... I'm gonna cry.
Very interesting theory, but, you overlook one very important point.
And that is?
Is stupid. Is most stupid theory I ever heard.
Something isn't right in all of this, eh. I can feel it in my buns.
Your what?
My buns.
Buns? Your buns? You bought buns and you didn't tell me? Where are they? Where are the buns?
Oh! No, monsieur. The BONES in my body.
You should not speak with an accent when you know I am so hungry.
Tell me, as the only survivor, how did you deduce it was me?
Butler did it.
Since we cannot call for a doctor, I will need a cold compress for my chaffeur, and a cup of hot chocolate for me, n'est ce pa?
I don't think we have any Nespa, sir. Just Hershey's.
Everything here has been rented for tonight. The butler, the cook, the food, the dining room chairs, everything!
You mean...
Yes. This entire murder has been... catered.
Look all over him.
All over his body?
Well, somebody's gotta do it. I'm busy standing guard.
Why don't I stand guard? You look all over the body.
All right, we'll take turns. You look over the first dead, naked body that we find and I'll look over the second.
Touch nothing!
Will you stop saying "touch nothing?" We're all experienced criminologists. I find it insulting, debasing, and redundant to keep telling us to "touch nothing!"
Oh, be quiet, woman!
Up yours, fella!
everything goes to pot!
Why do I do all the dirty work, Pop?
'Cause your mother not here to do it.
Someone just put deadly snake in room. Wake me when it come near bed.
He was very good to me. He would take me to the circus and give me candy. We stopped going when I was about twenty-six. I'm sorry, Sam.
Twenty-six? What the hell kind of a circus was it?
He was arrested in 1932 in Chicago for selling pornographic Bibles. The D.A. couldn't make the charge stick when the church refused to turn over the Bibles.

[cutting-room floor-scene on the foggy road, near the movie's end; as the Wangs are departing from Twain Manor, they pass a vintage car heading up TO the Manor. The other car is driven by Holmes and Watson]
... I say, old boy! Could you possibly give us directions to - Hello, it's Mr. Sidney Wang!

[smoking his famous pipe]
Greetings, Mr. Wang.
Ah, greetings to you as well! You have something to ask, I believe. Directions to where?
Ah, yes! We've been "cordially invited to dinner and a murder," by a Mr. Lionel Twain.
*Lionel Twain?* Listen, you guys don't wanna...!

[cutting him off]
Never mind him, please. Here - you go up this road, past bridge to "22 Twain." No can miss it.
Ever so much obliged. Good day, then!
[he and Holmes drive off]
I don't get it, Pop! Why didn't you just tell them it was all a ripoff?
Ah, let idiots find out for themselves! Drive, please.
[Playing a game of deduction]
And you Mr. Charleston, did not approve of Mrs. Charleston dying her hair blond?
What do you mean?
Mrs. Charleston's hair red. You have blond hairs on shoulder. This means she has dyed red hair blond, then back again to red, or else you have been... So sorry, Wang is wrong.

[after the lights have gone out in Twain's dining room]
Be quiet everyone! I smell something! It's - Good God! - FRANKS AND BEANS!
I'm afraid that's all we have, sir.
What do you make of all of this, Wang?
Is confusing.

[from moose head]
IT! IT is confusing! Say your goddamn pronouns!
Is he dead?
With a thing like that in his back, in the long run, he's better off.
Room filled with empty people.
Oh, there, voice come from cow on wall...

[from moose head]
Moose, moose, you imbecile!
There's nothing on him 'til '46, when he was picked up in El Paso, Texas, for trying to smuggle a truckload of rich white Americans across the border into Mexico to pick melons.
I think we picked ourselves a queer bird, angel.
Wouldn't you know, out of gas.
I saw a station about five miles back, Sam.

[hands her a gas can]
I want you to know I'm gonna be waitin' for ya, baby.
Here's the bridge, Pop. Doesn't look safe to me.
One way to find out. Drive across.
[gets out of car]
Aren't you gonna come with me?
Weight of two men may be too much for bridge.
Then why do I get to drive the car?
'Cause I smart enough to get out first.
May I get your bags, sir?
Oh, no, no. Son will get bags. That is why I adopted him.

[driving across rickety bridge]
I don't think I'm gonna make it, Pop. It's gonna collapse.
Don't worry. Father find other way to house.
What that?
[points to large cage in wall]
Oh, it's nothing, sir. Just the cat.
[loud barking and growling issues from cage]
That cat? You feed cat dog food?
I'm afraid he's a very angry cat, sir. Mr. Twain had him "fixed," and he didn't want to be.

[inspecting their room]
This dust is baking flour. And those cobwebs. Candied sugar. All placed here recently for the sole purpose of frightening us. And that mouse. Obviously a mechanical toy.
[picks up mouse and laughs]
Silly.
What is?
I am. It's real.
[stumbling around during a blackout]
Dickie, don't. You know how I get when you touch me there.
Me, darling? I've got my hands in my pockets.
I'm afraid they're my pockets.
Oh, sorry about that.
Dickie, behave yourself.
What meaning of this, Mr. Twain?

I will tell you, Mr. Wang, if YOU can tell ME why a man who possesses one of the most brilliant minds of this century can't say his *prepositions* or *articles!* "What IS THE," Mr. Wang! "What IS THE meaning of this?"
That what I said! "What meaning of this?"
How do I look so young? Quite simple. A complete vegetable diet, twelve hours sleep a night, and *lots* and *lots* of makeup.
You say you know who's going to get it?
Intimately.
And you know how the crime is to be committed?
Definitely.
And exactly what time murder to take place?
*The* murder. Precisely.
Well, I know it's none of my business, but doesn't that mean that you're the murderer, Mr. Twain?
I'm scared, Sam. Hold me.
Hold yourself. I'm busy.
Shut up, all of ya's. Nobody move!
What is it?
I have to go to the can again. I don't wanna miss nothin'.
Now let's see what we have here. We have one missing, dead, naked butler, one host with a butcher's knife in his back, and one poisonous scorpion crawling up our sheets.
Is that what that is?
Yes. They can kill instantly. I suggest we don't move.
For how long?
Quite possibly for the rest of our lives.
I'll be around if you need me. All you gotta do is whistle, and you know how to whistle, don't ya, baby?
Certainly. What do you mean? I don't understand you...
All right, never mind. Forget it. You ruined it.
I never did nothin' to a man that I wouldn't do to a woman.
In need of a hint Miss Marbles? You all mistake what you assume. THEY NEVER LEFT THE DINING ROOM! Count the numbers one to ten, turn the knob and try again!
I don't get it. First they steal the body and leave the clothes, then they take the clothes and bring the body back. Who would do a thing like that?
Possibly some deranged dry cleaner.
Someone gone great trouble to make welcome guests not so welcome. Ring bell, please.
Are you nuts, Pop? Someone's tryin' to KILL us!
Yes! Should make exciting weekend. Ring, please.

[sullen]
I sure wish it was Monday morning.
Mr. Diamond, there's a bullet hole in your jacket.
You should see the other guy.
I'm not a Frenchie, I'm a BELGIE!
Murderpoo?
Yes, dear, we're going to have a lovely murderpoo.
That drives me crazy!
Sounds like a short ride to me.
What a godforsaken spot to get lost!
I'm sure I saw a much better spot a few miles back.
His mother was a Roman Catholic, his father was an Orthodox Jew. They were separated two hours after the marriage.
No pinkies? You mean Twain has only got eight fingers?
No, no, he's got ten. He just doesn't have any pinkies.
Where were ya Wang, we was worried!

[hanging up telephone]
Sounded as though somebody snipped the wire.
Really? What did it sound like?
Snip.
He had one daughter, thirty-two, her name's Irene, but she calls herself Rita.
Just like a dame.
Oh, Yes. As you can see, I can see.
So I see.
My feet are killing me. Why didn't you tell me we needed oil before I went back for gas?
hard to get around.
I don't feel good about this, Sam. Maybe tonight's the night your luck runs out.
Maybe so. There's a number on the wall for all of us, angel, and if tonight's the night they pick mine, so be it. After you, sweetheart.
Now, if one of you gentlemen would be so kind as to give my lady friend here a glass of cheap white wine, I'm going down the hall to find the can. I talk so much sometimes, I forget to go.
I get fifty dollars a day plus expenses when I can get 'em, gentlemen. And I owe Miss Skeffington here three years and two month's back pay. Isn't that right, angel?
I don't care about the money, Sam.
Neither do I.
Quiet, please. Observe strange sounds.
[the room is filled with hideous death-groans]
Good God! The face! It's coming from the face!
[Sure enough, that agonized moaning issues from the African death-mask on the wall]
The victim of that tribal ritual, actually going through his final moments of death! What could it mean?
It means dinner is ready, sir. We have no gong.

[reading the new maid's note]
"I think butler is dead. My name is Yetta. I don't work Thursdays."
I don't like it. I don't like it one bit.
I like it, but do not understand it.
Sh, sh, sh! Cow talk again.
Aha, stumped already. Need some clues, Monsieur Perrier?
Clues? I need no clues from you! I find my own clues, you demented lollipop!
Doors and windows will automatically open at dawn, and one of us here will be one million dollars richer, and one of us will be going to the gas chamber to be hung.
I don't understand. Why would anybody want to steal a dead, naked body?
Well, dear, there are people who, um...
[whispers rest into her ear]
Oh, that's tacky! That's REALLY tacky!
How lovely dear! We're in Wang's wing!
One moment, where is the soup?
In your dish, sir!
There is nothing in my dish but my dish.
Now see here, Diamond. That's a pretty tacky thing to say, isn't it?
Well, it's a pretty tacky world, Mr. Charleston.
No, no, it's all right. My wine is not poisoned. It was just a bad year.
What is it? What's happened?
Something wrong in kitchen.
With our dinner!
No, patience, patience.
Is someone in there?
[pointing to kitchen]
Someone in the kitchen with dinna?
Quickly. Go back in kitchen, get dining room key from pocket of dead butler.
You don't have to say "dead butler." It's bad enough I have to put my hand in his pocket.
Maybe I'm just a patsy being set up take the fall, but I'm not falling for any o'yous, you understand?
Not even me, Sam?
Why don't you fall in love with the Jap kid and get off my back?
I don't get it, Pop. Who would hire a blind butler?
Very clever. How much he know he get paid?

[after Wang demonstrates his wine was poisoned]
Great Scott Mr. Wang, you've saved our lives.
Not quite, Mrs. Charleston. Bon Apetit
[drinks wine - company gasps and exclaims]
Mr. Twain is both beguiling and fiendish.
[crys out]
Mon Amis!
Oh get a doctor quick!
No, no, it's alright, my wine is not poisoned. It was just a bad year.
Sam, why do you keep all those naked muscle men magazines in your office?
Suspects. Always looking for suspects.
Excuse me, I was wondering if you've seen a white... Wang!
A white wang?
Butler only killed to divert us from real murder still to come.
Look at invitation. What number of house?
Correct. 22 Twain's
[choo choo train, i.e., Lionel Train]
house. Continue.
Good God. What an entrance.
[everyone holds hands to prevent themselves from being killed]
Stop that. Stop that, I said.
What is it, Diamond?
The nurse is giving my palm the finger, the dirty old broad.
[Hearing a knock at the door]
Oh, that's probably the cook. Come in!
Darling, the poor woman is stone deaf.
I'm sorry, I forgot. COME IN!
I'm not one to use hyperbole, ladies and gentlemen but I'll tell you this, for the first time in my life I had the caca scared out of me!
Dickie, I like her I really like her!
Why don't you push her wheelchair down the driveway? We got business here!
That was then, this is now, and nobody knows what tomorrow will be. That's the way things are, whether we like it or not.
Oh, Sam, I worry about you sometimes. I really do.
Good evening. We have been expecting you.
Yes, but in what condition?
Mr. Twain has macabre sense of humor, yes?
Holy Shanghai!
The lady here in the rented dress is my secretary and mistress, Miss Tess Skeffington.
Never consider murder to be business, Mr. Diamond.
I trust you've all been made comfortable?
Comfortable, Mr. Twain? You call poisoned wine and near decapitation comfortable?
No. I call it inspiration.
Have admired you ever since I was tiny little detective.
You pit your wits with me, little man, and you won't have your wits to pit with, know what I mean?
If you ask me, anybody that offers a million bucks to solve a crime that ain't been committed yet has lost a lot more upstairs than his hair.
very soon get nowhere.
Oh be quiet! I'm sick of your fortune cookies!
Oh, man who is sick of fortune cookies...
[argument ensues]
Shhh, shhh... cow talk again!
No wives! I refuse to discuss this with wives!
What do you make of all this, Wang?

[long pause]
Is confusing.

[about Sam]
Bizarre little twit.
My hat's off to the man with the shiv in his back. Except for the fact that he's dead, he was no dope.
Where's my Dickie?
[everyone stares at her]
Sorry. Where's my husband?
A mannequin.
No, a dummy.
I want you to know, Dickie, that if you're the murderer, I'll still love you. I don't think it would be right for us to make love, but I'd still love you.
Good night, Dad.
Should have adopted pussycat.
Forgive me, but I was talking about patricide, not uncle-cide.
Sam, you're spitting on the nurse.

[introducing them]
My wife Dora. Inspector Perrier.
Très charmant.
[kisses her hand, then coughs]
I'm sorry. Our room is so dusty.
My fault. I should have blown first.
Open my door.
You have chocolate on your face.
What?
Ze candy bar. It is all over your face.
Imbecile! That's my moustache!
Lick it and see.

[licks his lips]
Wipe it off. My hands are sticky.

[licks handkerchief and begins wiping Perrier's face]
Hold still please... Sloppy!
Very interesting theory, Mr. Charleston, but you overlook one very important point.
And that is?
Is STUPID! Is most stupid theory I ever heard.
[laughs]

[Cutting-room floor-scene of the Charlestons driving through heavy fog to Twain Manor]
... You know something, darling? I smell crime in the air.
I'm not surprised. You just ran over a small animal.
Did I? Oh, sorry about that... LOOK OUT!
[he slams on the brakes to avoid hitting Tess]
... Hello out there! Are you hurt?

[exhausted from walking]
... Oh, I'm fine - I just hiked five miles back this way from the gas station. Thank Heavens you saw me when you did.
Oh yes, I wouldn't want blood on my hands twice in one night. Well, keep to the side of the road.
[he drives off, leaving Tess standing there!]

[reading note from mute cook]
I think butler is dead! My name is Yetta, I don't work Thursdays.
Ask her if she sleeps in, Dickie!
I hope he knows how to stop that thing.
Did ya ever make it with a waitress?
I beg your your pardon?

A waitress. Big, fat waitress. I don't know what them society dames are like in the kit, but you ain't never had it 'til you made it with a big, fat, blondie waitress. If you're ever interested, you give me a call.
Jessie, baby!
Marvin Metzlah!
I prefer to be called... Rita!
